title: David Burke suing Chris Shea over poached employees
text:
Noam Galai The lawsuit said Chris Shea, who had been the executive chef at David Burke's (pictured) restaurant since 2011, used confidential knowledge of what employees were paid to offer higher salaries to those who jumped ship. BURKE FEELING BURNED BY FORMER EMPLOYEE
Poaching salmon is one thing, but poaching employees is another.
The restaurant group run by David Burke is suing "Top Chef Masters" star Chris Shea for extracting three top chefs from Burke's camp when Shea left it earlier this year to become executive chef at the Wayfarer in Midtown, reports the Daily News' Barbara Ross.
In a lawsuit filed in Manhattan Supreme Court, the Burke Group is accusing Shea of "blatantly and repeatedly" violating his contract, in which he agreed not to solicit co-workers for 18 months after leaving the organization.
However, "almost immediately after resigning . . . (Shea) mounted an extensive poaching campaign in which he actively encouraged at least five Burke Group employees - and likely far more - to . . . join him," court papers say.
The lawsuit said Shea, who had been the executive chef at David Burke's Kitchen since 2011, used confidential knowledge of what employees were paid to offer higher salaries to those who jumped ship.
Three "highly skilled" employees left "en masse," causing "substantial damage to the Burke Group" by disrupting business and damaging morale, Burke's firm claims.
The lawsuit said Shea's old contract required him to pay Burke twice his salary as executive chef as a penalty for violating the pact. The Burke Group is also asking the court to bar Shea from hijacking any more of his former co-workers.
Shea didn't respond to requests for comment.
'DEAD' STAR WANTS LIVING HISTORY
Sonequa Martin-Green , who plays the hard-edged Sasha Williams on AMC's "The Walking Dead," tells the November issue of Good Housekeeping magazine she wants to play a historical figure next. "I'd love to be in a biopic of someone who changed the landscape of America," says Martin-Green. "There are so many people so I don't have to name them, but just one of them. I'd also love to be a superhero as well . . . someone who does a lot of fighting - that would be amazing."

NAEEM SEES PURPLE FOR A GOOD CAUSE
Naeem Khan has revealed a special purple dress in honor of the upcoming Alzheimer's Association Rita Hayworth Gala. As a part of the collaboration, Khan, a longtime supporter of the charity, designed the custom gown the official color of the Alzheimer's cause, and it will be auctioned off at the Oct. 27 gala in New York. The money made from the auction will directly benefit the Alzheimer's Association. The designer debuted his piece alongside Marie Claire creative director and "Project Runway" judge Nina Garcia.

Designer John Varvatos was seen chatting with World of McIntosh executives at the WOM Townhouse launch event on Tuesday night about a possible future collaboration with the brand, we hear. Guests at the bash explored the five-story showroom with Keith Haring artwork on display in the pool room and a space for guests to play with WOM's high-end PRYMA Headphones. Grammy award-winning violinist Joshua Bell treated guests to a special performance of Vitali's "Chaconne for Violin," a song he hadn't performed since he was 13.

LEMON CHICKEN FOR CNN BIGS
CNN President Jeff Zucker and "CNN Tonight" anchor Don Lemon dined at Michael and Jenna Morton 's La Cave Wine & Food Hideaway inside Wynn Las Vegas Tuesday night following the Democratic presidential debate. The two enjoyed a late-night dinner on La Cave's patio, chowing down on mini-burgers, chicken and sausage flatbreads, charcuterie boards, chicken lollipops and crudités with hummus made by executive chef Billy DeMarco . The pair also sipped Sancerre Sauvignon Blanc and Punto Final Malbec.
